body: PASSIN-Mae, 66, of San Diego, CA., formerly of Mill Basin, Brooklyn, NY and El Paso, TX, died on September 30, 1997. She is survived by her husband Frank; son Howard, daughter Sheila; two grandsons Steven and Cliff, all residing in San Diego, CA.; and a sister Sylvia Ness of Teaneck, NJ.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PASSIN, MAE

body: On one side of the wall, a sweaty quest for redemption -- or at least a clean criminal record -- unfolded. On the other, a tranquil search for salvation continued, as it has for almost a century. Approximately 30 men (plus a few women) who had been convicted of crimes ranging from fare beating to heroin possession to assault, and given community
title: Convicts Wash Away Their Misdeeds Along With Graffiti

body: Shortly after Gurmeet Singh Dhinsa arrived in the United States a dozen years ago, he began to build an empire of gas stations that would earn him a fortune. But he also began to break the laws of his adopted country, law enforcement officials say, and to build a reputation among some of the city's Sikh immigrants as a man of violence. But in
title: Police Say Man Stopped at Nothing for Gasoline Empire

body: THE old trapper stopped a moment to wipe his hands, the blood staining fingerprints into his pants leg, spittle popping inside the wood-burning stove. He took up another muskrat, made two small incisions around its ankles and cut up under the tail, opening the vermin like a paper bag. Nailing its tail to the rafter, he peeled the skin back,
title: Last Days Of the Baymen

body: Hours before the high drama of a Presidential tribute to Jackie Robinson before 54,000 fans at Shea Stadium, a teen-age Brooklyn boy threatened Mr. Clinton with death and said a bomb had been planted in the ballpark in Queens, the police said yesterday. The 13-year-old boy telephoned his threats to an operator just before 3 P.M. on Tuesday from a
title: Brooklyn Boy Threatens Clinton and Is Arrested

body: For a decade, city officials have boasted that nearly three-quarters of New York's streets were acceptably clean. In February, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani released the city's latest self-evaluation, a survey that said 83 percent of the streets were clean -- a remarkable figure considering substantial cuts in the Sanitation Department's budget in
title: A Review Finds the City Dirtier Than It Says It Is
